novel_text:
The dust of the prairie was a thing you learned to live with, a fine grit that settled in the lines of your palms and the back of your throat. For Russell, it was the only constant besides the sky. That vast, aching blue, so big it could swallow a man’s soul and not even burp. He rode the fenceline on a gelding named Dust, a fitting name for a creature made of the same earth as the endless fields of canola and wheat that stretched out like a rumpled golden sheet. The horse knew his thoughts better than he did, its ears twitching back to catch the low hum of anxiety that lived just under Russell’s ribs. A hum that had started a few months ago, right around the time the nights started getting a bite to them.

He worked for a man named Miller, whose face was a roadmap of sun and worry. Miller never asked questions, just pointed at a task—a broken fence, a sick calf, a tractor that coughed black smoke—and Russell would do it. The work was honest. It was real. The splinter in his thumb was real. The sweat that he was sure should be trickling down his spine, though he never quite felt its dampness, was real. The world made a certain kind of sense from the back of a horse. Earth below, sky above, and the horizon a promise that never got any closer.

But the evenings were different. The evenings were for her.

He’d scrubbed the day’s grime from under his nails, the scent of antiseptic soap a sharp intruder against the familiar smells of hay and leather. He wore the same thing every Tuesday and Thursday: clean jeans, a pearl-snap shirt, and boots he’d polished to a dull gleam. He’d drive his old Ford, a machine of rust and hope, into Saskatoon, the city lights a false constellation on the flat earth. The university building felt like a different planet, all clean lines and the hushed whisper of central heating. It smelled of floor wax and old paper. He always felt too big for the hallways, his shoulders wanting to hunch against the narrowness of it all.

The class was called ‘Histories of the Forgotten’. It sounded like a sad song, and maybe that’s what drew him in. Room 2B. He’d sit in the back, near the window, where he could see the last vestiges of twilight surrender to the sodium-lamp orange of the parking lot. The other students were ghosts to him, their chatter a meaningless surf. He was there for one reason.

Her name was Elara Vance.

She wasn’t from here. You could tell by the way she said ‘Saskatoon’, like it was a word she’d found in an exotic book. She was a slip of a thing, with hair the colour of dark honey that she’d twist up with a pen when she was making a point, and eyes that were the grey of a storm gathering over the ocean. An ocean Russell had only ever seen in pictures. She spoke of history not as a collection of dates and dead kings, but as a living, breathing thing. A wound that never quite healed. She’d pace in front of the whiteboard, her hands moving as she spoke, weaving stories of ghost ships and lost explorers, of languages that had been spoken for a thousand years and then vanished in a single generation.

“History isn’t written by the victors,” she’d said one night, her gaze sweeping the room and, for a heartbeat, landing on him. “It’s written by the survivors. And the real stories, the most important ones, belong to those who didn’t survive to tell them. Our job is to listen for the echoes.”

Russell listened. He listened so hard the world outside the window would dissolve. He didn’t care about the Carthaginian navy or the lost colony of Roanoke, not really. He cared about the passion in her voice, the way a faint flush would rise on her cheeks when she was deep in a story. He cared about the small, sad smile that touched her lips when she spoke of things lost to time. He felt like one of those lost things, and he yearned for her to find him.

Tonight, she was talking about the sea. About sailors and the superstitions that guided them, the belief that the ocean was a hungry god, that it remembered every soul it took. She put up a slide of a painting, all churning green water and a single, splintered mast.

“They believed the sea had a memory,” she said, her voice dropping to a near whisper. “That the souls of the drowned were bound to it, forever drifting in the cold, silent depths. They weren’t ghosts in the traditional sense, not haunting a house. They were haunting an element. Water. Imagine that. To be tied not to a place, but to a state of being.”

A strange feeling, cold and heavy, settled in Russell’s gut. It was a familiar feeling, a companion he’d mistaken for loneliness. He looked down at his hands, resting on the worn wooden desk. The skin was pale, the knuckles like white stones. He could never seem to get them warm. He flexed his fingers, a slow, deliberate movement. He was here. He was solid. The desk was solid. He was not haunting the water. He was a cowboy from Saskatoon. He was just a man, sitting in a classroom, falling in love. It was the simplest, most human thing in the world.

He risked a look at her. She was staring at the painting, her expression distant, her grey eyes reflecting the turmoil of the painted waves. He felt a sudden, sharp pang of something he couldn't name. It was more than just a crush, more than the simple heat he saw in the eyes of the other ranch hands when they talked about women. This was different. It was a deep, unsettling recognition, like he’d been searching for her for a hundred years and was terrified she might vanish before he could say a word.

The class ended. The other students scraped their chairs back, their chatter rushing in to fill the reverent silence Elara had created. They gathered their things, their lives spilling out in snippets of conversation about exams and weekend plans. Russell didn’t move. He waited, his heart a slow, heavy drum against his ribs. It was a rhythm he could feel more than hear. He waited until it was just him and her in the room.

She was erasing the whiteboard, her movements methodical. The ghosts of her chalk-written words vanished in a soft white cloud. He could smell the chalk dust, a dry, mineral scent.

“Russell,” she said, not turning around. She knew he was still there. She always knew. “Did you have a question about the Franklin Expedition?”

He cleared his throat. The sound was rough, unused. “No, ma’am.”

She turned then, a small smile on her face. It was the smile that undid him every time. “You don’t have to call me ma’am, you know. Elara is just fine.”

“Elara,” he repeated. The name felt strange and wonderful in his mouth. “I just… I liked what you said. About haunting an element.”

Her smile deepened. She leaned back against the desk, crossing her arms. It was a gesture that should have been defensive, but on her, it looked thoughtful. “It’s a romantic notion, isn’t it? To be part of something so vast. The prairie is like that, too, I think. This sky… it must get into your bones, living under it your whole life.”

He nodded, unable to form a proper reply. He felt like his bones were made of dust and wind, that a good gust could scatter him across the plains. “You talk about the sea a lot,” he said, the words coming out quieter than he intended. “You miss it?”

Her expression shifted. The smile faded, replaced by that familiar, beautiful sadness. “I do. I grew up on the coast. My father was a sailor. He used to say the sea sings a song, and once you’ve heard it, no other music ever sounds quite right.” She looked past him, out the window into the dark. “He went out on a trawler twelve years ago and never came back. The sea just… kept him.”

There it was again. That cold, heavy thing inside him. He understood loss. He knew what it was to be left behind. The feeling was so sharp, so clear, that for a moment he felt a kinship with her lost father. He, too, felt adrift.

“I’m sorry,” he said.

“Don’t be.” She gave a little shake of her head, as if to clear it. “It’s just history, right? Another story for the forgotten.” She gathered her leather satchel, her movements suddenly brisk. “Well, I should be going. Have a good night, Russell.”

He wanted to say something else. Something important. Ask her to stay, to tell him another story. Tell her she looked like an angel under the harsh fluorescent lights. But the words were stones in his throat. He just nodded. “You too.”

He watched her walk out, the soft click of her heels echoing in the empty hall. He stayed in the classroom for a long time, sitting in the silence. He looked at the painting of the shipwreck, still projected on the screen. The churning, endless water. He imagined a man out there, lost in the green-black depths, his soul tangled in the currents, listening to a song only he could hear.

Walking out of the building was like stepping through a veil. The cold night air hit him, but it was a distant sensation, like watching a movie of a man feeling cold. He could see his breath plume in front of his face, a ghostly white cloud, but the chill didn't bite at his lungs. It never did. He zipped his jacket out of habit, not necessity.

The parking lot was mostly empty. His truck sat under a lonely lamp, looking tired. He didn’t walk towards it. Instead, he found himself walking the other way, towards the river that sliced the city in two. The Meewasin Valley trail was dark, the path a suggestion more than a reality. The bare branches of the cottonwoods clawed at the night sky. He stood on the edge of the riverbank, looking at the black water sliding silently past. A few shards of ice clung to the shore, glittering like broken glass. The city was a string of lights on the far bank, a world away.

He didn't know why he came here. It was a pull, a compulsion. The same way he was pulled to her class. The same way he was pulled to the fenceline at dawn. He felt a profound sense of stillness, as if he were a part of the landscape, a figure in a painting that never moved. A car passed on the bridge above, its headlights sweeping over him for a second. He didn't flinch. He wasn't even sure the driver could have seen him. He felt… transparent.

He thought about Elara. About the sea. About her father. He thought about being tied to an element. Water. Earth. Sky. He pressed his hand against the frozen trunk of a poplar tree. The bark was rough, real. He felt the texture, but not the cold. He was a cowboy. His name was Russell. He lived on Miller’s ranch just outside of Saskatoon. He was taking a night class. These were the facts. These were the fence posts of his reality. But lately, the wire between them felt loose, humming with a strange, low frequency. A song, maybe. A song he was just beginning to hear. And it sounded a little bit like the sea. He turned his face up to the vast, empty dark and wondered, not for the first time, if the sky was swallowing him whole, or if it had already spit him out.The drive back was a reverse pilgrimage, away from the electric shrine of the city and back into the deep, scriptural dark of the country. The headlights of his Ford cut a fleeting, dusty tunnel through the night, illuminating nothing but the next few feet of gravel and the ghosts of last summer’s cattails in the ditches. The radio was broken, but he wouldn’t have turned it on anyway. The silence in the cab was a living thing, a space for his thoughts to unspool. He thought of Elara’s face when she spoke of her father, a grief so old it had become a part of her architecture, like the load-bearing walls of a house. He recognized it because he felt its phantom weight in his own chest, a sorrow for a loss he couldn’t name or remember.

Miller’s ranch was a dark island in an ocean of black land, the only light a single yellow bulb above the main barn door, buzzing with frantic moths. He parked the truck near his small, detached cabin, a simple clapboard box that was once a tack shed. The other ranch hands were long asleep in the bunkhouse, their snores a low, rumbling counterpoint to the chirr of crickets. Russell didn’t go to the bunkhouse. He didn’t need to. Sleep was a country he no longer had a passport for. He’d tried, in the beginning. He’d lie down on the narrow cot, close his eyes, and wait. But nothing ever came. Just the darkness behind his eyelids and the ceaseless, low hum inside him. So now he just waited for the sun, a silent watchman for a dawn he felt no warmth from.

He sat in the single wooden chair in his cabin, the door open to the night. The air smelled of cooling earth and the faint, sweet decay of stubble in the fields. This was when the fence posts of his reality felt loosest. He tried to remember a time before Miller’s ranch, before the dust. He had no memories of parents, of a childhood home, of a school or a friend. His life, as far as he could recall it, began four months ago. It began in a field not five miles from here, with him on his back, staring up at that vast, indifferent sky. He remembered the taste of soil in his mouth and a confusion so profound it had no sharp edges, just a dull, pervasive fog. He’d sat up, and the gelding, Dust, had been standing a few feet away, watching him with patient, liquid eyes, as if he’d been waiting. Miller had found them both an hour later, Russell walking aimlessly along the fenceline, the horse trailing him like a shadow. Miller, his face a testament to a life of not being surprised by anything the prairie could throw at him, had simply grunted, pointed at the horse and said, “He looks like he’s yours.” And that had been that.

He had become Russell. He had learned the work, his body moving with a memory his mind didn’t have. He was a good hand. He was strong and tireless, because weariness was another sensation that seemed to happen to other people. The other hands respected him for it, though they kept their distance. There was a stillness about him they couldn't quite read, a quiet that wasn't peaceful. He was like a well you couldn’t see the bottom of. They’d joke that he was part-machine, part-ghost, and he would offer a smile that he knew didn’t quite reach his eyes. They were more right than they knew.

He stood and walked to the small, cracked mirror he’d tacked to the wall. In the gloom, his reflection was a suggestion, a sketch of a man. Dark hair, a strong jaw, eyes that seemed to absorb the low light and give nothing back. He was solid. He cast a shadow. But he felt like a placeholder, a story someone had started and then forgotten to finish. He thought of Elara’s words, a phrase that now echoed in the hollow spaces inside him. *Haunting an element.* She had been talking about the sea, about sailors lost to the green depths. But as he looked out the open door at the endless, rustling land under a canopy of cold stars, he felt a new and terrifying truth begin to settle. The dust was in the lines of his palms because it was what he was made of. The sky could swallow him because he had been born from its emptiness. He wasn’t a man haunted by the prairie. He was the prairie, haunting the shape of a man.The sun rose not with warmth, but with a flat, clinical light that laid bare the textures of the world. For Russell, dawn was no longer a promise of a new day but a simple turning of the page. The hum under his ribs was still there, but it had changed its tune overnight. It was no longer the thrum of anxiety but the resonant frequency of the land itself, a deep, geologic vibration he was now attuned to. As he swung a leg over Dust’s back, the worn leather of the saddle felt less like a tool and more like a part of his own skin. The horse’s sigh was his sigh. The dust motes dancing in the slanted light were his own scattered thoughts.

Miller had tasked him with riding the north fenceline, checking for breaks where the deer had been pushing through. It was a task he’d done a dozen times, but today it was different. As Dust plodded along the familiar track, Russell saw the land not as a place he worked, but as a body he inhabited. The gentle roll of the hills was the slow rise and fall of a sleeping chest. The sloughs, shimmering with early light, were the land’s pooling thoughts. When he found a section of wire snapped and tangled, the wood of the post splintered and grey, he dismounted and felt a pang that was not of a worker finding more work, but of a man discovering a fresh wound on his own arm. He unwrapped the new wire from his saddle horn, his movements patient and sure. His hands, which had always felt like foreign objects, now seemed to be the perfect tools for this task. The bite of the wire against his calloused palms was not pain, but a confirmation of reality. He was mending.

He worked for hours, the sun climbing the vast dome of the sky. He did not sweat. He did not tire. The other hands would stop for water, for a rest in the sliver of shade cast by their horses. Russell did not. He was a perpetual motion machine fueled by something other than food and water. Miller drove out in his battered pickup around midday, a plume of dust announcing his arrival from a mile off. He pulled up, the engine idling, and watched Russell twist the last stay into place. Miller’s gaze, usually fixed on the task at hand, was on Russell himself.

“You get it all?” Miller asked, his voice a gravelly rumble.

“This was the last of it on the north line,” Russell said, coiling the leftover wire.

Miller nodded, his eyes, squinting against the glare, still fixed on him. “You don’t stop much, do you, son?” It wasn’t an accusation, just an observation, stated as plainly as noting the lack of clouds. He held out a metal water bottle. “Have a drink.”

It was a test. A simple, human gesture that Russell knew he had to perform. He took the bottle, the metal cool against his palm. He unscrewed the cap and raised it to his lips, tipping it back. The water was cold, shockingly so. He felt it slide down his throat, an alien liquid in a dry vessel. It did not quench a thirst he didn't have; it simply filled a space. He swallowed and handed the bottle back. “Thanks.”

Miller grunted, taking the bottle. He didn't drink from it. He just looked at Russell for a long moment, a flicker of something unreadable in his sun-worn face—not suspicion, maybe not even curiosity, but a deep, weary acknowledgement, as if he were looking at a familiar ghost. “Get back before dark,” he said, and drove away, leaving Russell alone again with the sky and the endless, humming wire.

The rest of the day was a meditation. He was no longer a man riding a horse. He was a thought moving across a landscape, a single, conscious cell on a vast, living organism. The world made a terrifying, perfect sense. But as the sun began its slow descent, painting the western sky in bruised purples and fiery orange, a different kind of pull began to assert itself. It was the pull of Room 2B. It was the pull of her. The hum inside him shifted its key again, from the deep drone of the earth to a higher, more urgent frequency. A yearning. It was Wednesday. There was no class. It didn't matter.

He drove the Ford back into the city, the journey feeling more urgent, more necessary than ever before. He didn't go to the university building. He couldn't bear its sterile, empty hallways without her in them. Instead, he parked a block away from an address he'd found in a university staff directory he’d looked up at the public library, his heart pounding with a rhythm that felt both foreign and his own. It was a small, two-story house with a porch light that cast a warm, yellow glow, a beacon of life in the quiet, tree-lined street. Her car, a modest blue sedan, was parked in the driveway.

He just sat in his truck in the deepening twilight, an unseen watcher. He felt like a creature of the dark peering into a campfire's glow. He saw lights flick on in the house. He saw her silhouette pass a window, a brief, graceful shadow that made his chest ache. She was in there, living a life. A life of books and tea and the scent of floor wax and old paper. A life of memories, of a father and the sea. A human life. And he was out here, a man made of dust and twilight, his entire remembered existence barely a season old. The chasm between their worlds felt as wide and as deep as the ocean she missed.

He watched for an hour as the house settled into the quiet rhythms of a weeknight. He saw another shadow join hers, taller. A man. They stood in the frame of the kitchen window for a moment, and even from this distance, he could see the easy familiarity in their posture. He saw the man’s arm go around her shoulders, and he saw her lean into the embrace. A simple, casual gesture of affection that struck Russell with the force of a physical blow. The cold, heavy thing in his gut, the thing he had mistaken for loneliness, coalesced into a sharp, piercing icicle of pure pain. It was a feeling so human, so raw, it almost made him feel real.

He started the truck, the engine's rusty cough sounding unnaturally loud in the quiet street. He had to get away. He was a fool. A ghost at a banquet, starving for a feast he could never taste. What was he thinking? That she would find him? That she would see the lost history in his eyes and want to read it? He was a story with no words, a wound that couldn't bleed. He drove out of the city, the false constellations of the streetlights blurring in his vision, though his eyes were dry. He did not weep. He wasn’t sure if he could. He was just an echo, and the sound he was making was a name he had only just learned to say aloud. Elara.## Chapter 2

The pain was a clean, sharp thing, and for that he was almost grateful. It was different from the low, constant hum he lived with, the background radiation of his own strange existence. This was a signal, a specific frequency of hurt that proved he was tuned to something human after all. Driving away from her house, the Ford’s engine was the only sound, a mechanical groan against the vast, geological silence of the prairie night. The city lights receded in his rearview mirror until they were just a smear, like a thumbprint of grief on a pane of dark glass. He was a creature of the open plains, and that brief, painful glimpse into a walled garden of warmth and intimacy had been a trespass. He had seen a language of touch and belonging that he knew, with a sudden and devastating certainty, he would never learn to speak.

He did not go back to his cabin right away. He parked the truck and walked out into the nearest fallow field, the stiff, dry stubble crunching under his boots. The moon was a sliver of bone in the black sky, offering no comfort, only a stark, silvered reality. He stood for a long time, letting the night pour into him, hoping it would wash away the image of her leaning into another man’s embrace. But it stayed, branded behind his eyes. He was a story with no words, and he had just seen a poem he would never be able to read. He pressed his palm flat against the cold, packed earth. He felt the vibration of it, the deep, slow pulse of the continent. This was his. This was real. The dirt, the dust, the endless space. He had been born of it, and he would un-become into it. It was a cold comfort, but it was the only one he had.

Thursday dawned grey and grudging, the sky the colour of unpolished steel. Russell was up before the first light, his body moving with the grim purpose of a machine. He sought out Miller before the other hands were even stirring. The old rancher was in the barn, his breath pluming as he checked on a newborn calf. He looked up as Russell approached, his eyes sharp and assessing in the dim light. Before Miller could point him to a task, Russell spoke, his voice quiet but firm. “The west quarter. The one you want for alfalfa. I’ll clear the stones.” Miller’s eyebrows raised a fraction. It was the worst job on the ranch, a brutal, soul-crushing task of prying and hauling glacial rock from the soil, work usually done by two or three men over the course of a week. For one man, it was a punishment. Miller stared at him, then gave a slow, deliberate nod. “Suit yourself,” he said, turning back to the calf.

The work was a kind of savage prayer. He used a long iron pry bar, sinking it into the earth beside a half-buried stone, and then threw his entire weight against it. The muscles in his back and shoulders bunched and strained, but he felt no burn, no ache. He was a lever, a simple machine doing a simple, violent task. The stones, some the size of bread loaves, others the size of a dog, grudgingly gave up their hold on the earth. He hauled them one by one to a growing pile at the edge of the field, a cairn to his own futility. He worked with a frantic, unflagging rhythm, a piston of flesh and bone. He was trying to exhaust the feeling out of himself, to replace the sharp memory of Elara with the dull, heavy reality of stone. He wanted to be so empty that there was no room for anything else. But with every rock he heaved, her face rose in his mind. The passion in her eyes when she spoke of lost things. The small, sad smile. The way she had turned to him, just for a heartbeat.

As the sun reached its zenith, the hum beneath his ribs returned, a persistent thrumming that the labour could not silence. It was the call to Room 2B. The thought of going was absurd, a self-inflicted wound. He was a fool, a prairie ghost who’d mistaken a flicker of warmth for a home. He should stay here, in his element, surrounded by the honest realities of dirt and rock. He should forget the smell of old paper and chalk dust, forget the cadence of her voice weaving stories in the dark. But the pull was not rational. It was a tide. He knew, with a sense of grim resignation, that he had no more choice in the matter than a compass needle has in pointing north. He was tethered to her, and the rope was pulling him in, whether he liked it or not.

The ritual of preparing for class felt like a mockery. He scrubbed his hands raw, the scent of antiseptic soap failing to cover the mineral smell of the earth that was ground deep into his skin. He put on the clean shirt, the polished boots. He was a man dressing up to attend his own haunting. The drive into Saskatoon was a silent battle. Every mile that brought him closer to the university felt like a step towards a cliff’s edge. He saw the lights of the city again, and this time they looked like scattered embers from a fire he couldn't get close to. He didn’t want to see her. He had to see her. The contradiction was a physical weight in his chest, heavy and cold as the stones he’d been lifting all day.

He was late. He stood outside the classroom door, listening to the muffled sound of her voice. She was talking about cartography, about the blank spaces on old maps marked ‘Here Be Dragons’. He felt like one of those blank spaces, a territory of unknown fears and forgotten histories. His hand rested on the door handle, the metal cold and definite against his palm. He could turn around. He could get in his truck, drive back to the ranch, and lose himself in the familiar dark. He could build a wall of stone and dust and silence around himself so high that no echo could ever reach him again. But he knew he wouldn’t. Because whatever he was, whatever strange, half-life he was living, it had begun to circle around her. She was the gravitational center of his new, bewildering world.

With a breath he didn't need, he opened the door. The soft click of the latch was deafening. Her voice stopped mid-sentence. Every student turned to look at the interruption. And her eyes, those storm-grey eyes, found his. There was a flicker of surprise, and something else he couldn't read. Concern? Annoyance? He gave no nod of apology, no self-conscious shrug. He felt transparent, a figure of smoke moving through the room. He walked to his usual seat in the back, near the window, every step feeling deliberate and impossibly heavy. The other students turned back to the front, the brief ripple of his arrival smoothing over. He sat down and stared, not at the map on the screen, but at her. She hesitated for another moment, her gaze still on him, before she picked up the thread of her lecture. He was here again, in the place of his undoing, listening to the music that had broken him, and he didn't know why, other than he could not stay away.He sat in his chair, a stone in a river of meaningless chatter that preceded the lecture's start. He could not look away from her. The sight of her was a fresh turn of the knife. He saw her now not as a solitary figure of passion and sad smiles, but as one half of a pair. Her hands, which wove such compelling stories in the air, had rested in another’s. Her voice, which held the attention of the entire room, likely softened to a whisper in the quiet of her home for another man. The thought was a physical weight, pressing down on him, making the air in the room feel thin and useless. She began to speak, her voice as clear and captivating as ever, but for Russell, the spell was broken. The words were just sounds. He was no longer listening for echoes of the forgotten; he was listening to the voice of a woman who belonged to someone else.

When the lecture concluded, the spell of her storytelling dissolving into the scrape of chairs and the mundane talk of exams, Russell moved with them. For the first time, he did not wait. The ritual was tainted, the hope that had invisibly anchored him to his seat now exposed as a fool’s errand. There was no point in waiting for a brief, polite exchange that would only deepen the ache. Staying would be an act of profound self-deception. He had to leave. He had to get back to the honest silence of the fields, to the company of dust and wind, which made no promises and could not break his heart. He slung his jacket over his shoulder and joined the anonymous flow of students heading for the door, his gaze fixed on the floor, a man trying to disappear into the crowd. He was almost at the threshold, a step away from the freedom of the empty hallway.

“Russell.”

Her voice was not loud, but it cut through the din and stopped him cold. It was a physical tether, pulling him back from the edge. He paused in the doorway, the last few students squeezing past him with curious glances. He felt their eyes on him, on the strange, silent man from the back row being singled out. Slowly, he turned. The room was empty now, save for the two of them. She stood by the lectern, her satchel not yet gathered, her arms crossed in that thoughtful way she had. The projected map of the world, with its vast, unexplored oceans, was a backdrop for the space that now stretched between them.

“Are you alright?” she asked, her grey eyes searching his face. There was no artifice in her tone, only genuine, unsettling concern. “You seem… elsewhere tonight.”

He felt the muscles in his jaw tighten. He wanted to tell her. He wanted to pour out the whole strange, impossible story—the field, the horse, the lack of memory, the cold that never touched him, the way he had felt a flicker of life for the first time listening to her speak. But the words were not his to command. They were buried too deep, under layers of dust and silence. “Just tired,” he managed, the words scraping his throat. “Long day.”

She didn't look convinced. She took a step closer, her expression softening. “You work on a ranch, don’t you? Miller’s place?” He just nodded, surprised she knew the name. Her gaze drifted past him for a moment, towards the map still glowing on the screen. “I was thinking about what we were discussing,” she said, her voice dropping a little. “Those blank spaces. ‘Here Be Dragons.’ It’s a warning, but it’s also an invitation, isn’t it? To the brave or the desperate.” She looked back at him, her eyes holding his with a startling intensity. “The men who sailed into them weren’t always looking for treasure or glory. Sometimes, I think, they were just running from something. Trying to find a place so new it could wash them clean of the past.”

He stood there, frozen, the weight of her perception pressing down on him more heavily than any stone he had lifted that day. She saw him. She didn't know what he was, but she saw the shape of his emptiness. She saw the flight in him, the desperate search for a shore he couldn’t name. He had come here, to this room, feeling like a ghost, and she had just described his very soul as if it were a lesson from one of her history books. The pain of seeing her with another man was still there, but now it was tangled with a new, more terrifying feeling: the profound and agonizing relief of being seen. He felt the phantom ache in his back from clearing rocky soil, a different kind of labour than his work on the ranch. He heard the murmur of Russian words and the soaring, unaccompanied harmonies of psalms in his mind, a music of such profound faith and sorrow it made his chest ache. He felt Stefan’s deep, abiding love for the land, a love that was a form of worship, and the sharp, bitter sting of being misunderstood by the very people with whom he shared that faith.

Leo Ozeroff lived in a small, weathered timber-frame house nestled in a narrow valley, surrounded by a meticulously kept garden and overshadowed by the immense, brooding presence of the mountains. He was a man in his late sixties, with a broad, stooped back and hands that were gnarled and powerful, the hands of a man who had worked with wood and earth his entire life. His eyes, set in a deeply lined face, were wary as he took in the sight of Elara and the strange, still man at her side. He led them into a simple, light-filled living room that smelled of cedar shavings and beeswax. He listened in silence as Elara, once again, explained her purpose, her voice low and respectful. She offered him the notebook. He took it, his large, rough hands surprisingly gentle as they cradled the small book. He stared at the cover, his face a mask of stoic neutrality. "My babushka," he said, his voice a low, gravelly rumble, "she never spoke of him. My father said he was a man who brought shame, who turned from the old ways and then walked away from his responsibilities. He said the land took him as a punishment."

"He never turned from his faith," Elara said softly. "He just believed it was strong enough to embrace a new world. Would you let me read you his words?" Leo gave a single, slow nod, his eyes never leaving the notebook in his hands. Elara opened it and began to read. She read of Stefan’s journey from Russia, the persecution, the dream of a peaceful life. She read of his love for his wife, a woman with hands that were always covered in flour, and of his deep, spiritual connection to the sunflowers he grew, which he saw as a thousand small suns paying homage to God. She read of the thresher, of his belief that it was not a tool of greed but a gift that would allow the community more time for prayer and family, and of the heartbreak he felt when they saw it as a sin, a doorway for the corrupting influence of the outside world. She read of his final walk, not an act of abandonment, but a desperate pilgrimage into the fields to ask God why his love was not enough.

As she read, the stoic mask on Leo’s face began to crack. A single tear traced a path through the sawdust ingrained in the lines of his cheek, then another. He was not just hearing a story; he was witnessing the restoration of his grandfather’s soul. When Elara finished, a heavy silence filled the room, broken only by the sound of the wind sighing in the tall pines outside. Leo slowly, reverently, opened the notebook himself, his finger tracing Elara’s script as if he could read the memory directly from the ink. "The psalm," he whispered, his voice thick with emotion. "The one about the seeds. My father used to hum it when he worked. He never sang the words, but I remember the tune." He looked up, his wary eyes now shining with a fierce, transformative light. He looked past Elara, at Russell, who stood by the window, a silent, elemental presence against the backdrop of the mountains. "It was not a punishment," Leo said, the words a revelation, a breaking of a generational curse. "It was a misunderstanding. A great, sad misunderstanding." That evening, Leo Ozeroff took Elara and Russell to the community hall, a simple, unadorned wooden building where the elders gathered for their weekly prayer service. He stood before them, a man unaccustomed to public speaking, holding his grandfather's story in his hands. His voice, rough and hesitant at first, grew strong and clear as he told the true story of Stefan Ozeroff, the man who had loved God, his family, and his sunflowers. He told them of his grandfather's faith and his heartbreak. And then, he closed the notebook, closed his eyes, and began to sing. He sang the old psalm, the one about the seeds, his voice a rich and powerful baritone filling the simple hall. After a moment of stunned silence, one of the old women joined in, then another, and then the entire room was filled with the soaring, complex, and beautiful harmonies of the Doukhobor choir. The music poured out of the open doors of the hall and echoed through the valley, a song of sorrow, of forgiveness, and of homecoming. The story had not just been returned to a family; it had been woven back into the living heart of a people.## Chapter 10

Leaving the Slocan Valley was like waking from a powerful dream. The soaring, multi-part harmonies of the Doukhobor choir seemed to have permanently imprinted themselves on the air, a lingering resonance that Elara could still feel vibrating in her chest as they drove east, leaving the monumental peaks of the Kootenays behind them. The delivery of Stefan Ozeroff’s story had been different from the first. In Peterborough, they had mended a tear in the private fabric of a single family, a quiet, intimate act of restoration. But here, they had witnessed a public healing, the rewriting of a communal narrative, the absolution of a man whose story had been a cautionary tale of shame and was now a testament of faith and sorrow. For Russell, the experience was a profound unburdening. He had felt the weight of Stefan’s story lift not just from his own consciousness, but from the very soil of the valley, a long-held tension in the land finally released, smoothed over by the grace of a song.

The journey back to the prairies was a reverse genesis. The world flattened, the sky reasserted its dominance, and the complex, vertical music of the mountains resolved back into the deep, foundational hum of the plains. Russell felt it the moment they left the foothills, a physical relaxation in his shoulders, a sense of returning to his own native frequency. Elara, now attuned to the land in a way she never could have imagined, felt it too, a subtle shift in the atmosphere, like a pressure change before a storm. The prairie was no longer a vast, empty space to her, but a presence. It was Russell’s source, the wellspring of his being, and returning to it felt like bringing a sailor back within sight of the sea. She watched his profile as he stared out the window, his expression placid and unreadable, and she knew he was home, even if home was a transient motel room a thousand kilometers from the basin that had birthed him.

Their next stop was a nondescript motel on the outskirts of Prince Albert, a place of cracked pavement and humming ice machines. The familiar ritual resumed, a sacred act performed in a profane space. While Russell stood outside in the gathering dark, his feet planted on a patch of withered grass, reacquainting himself with the specific voice of this patch of earth, Elara sat on the edge of the stiff, patterned bedspread and opened her laptop. She pulled the next notebook from the stack. The spine was worn, the pages filled with her swift, dense script. This was Joseph’s story. The Métis trapper who knew the land as a living relative, and who had walked into the basin not with fear or by accident, but with the calm intention of a man going to keep a long-held appointment. The first line she had transcribed from Russell’s telling echoed in her mind: “He was not taken; he went.” This story was different. It was not about a soul consumed by a lonely power, but about a man who understood a deeper bargain, a communion that transcended life and death.

Finding Joseph’s family presented a new and formidable challenge. The colonial records that had, however sparsely, documented the lives of settlers like Henderson and Peary were largely silent on the lives of the Métis. Names were fluid, families were mobile, and history was carried not in ledgers and census forms, but in stories, in songs, and in the deep memory of a people. Elara spent two days falling down a rabbit hole of genealogical dead-ends. The name ‘Joseph’ was ubiquitous. The notebook mentioned no surname. She searched through land scrip records, mission baptismal registries, and Hudson's Bay Company employment rolls, but without a family name, she was adrift in a sea of ghosts. Frustrated, she closed her eyes and tried to think like Russell, to listen to the story itself for clues. The notebook was filled with the details of Joseph’s life: the specific beadwork pattern his mother used on his moccasins, the name of his horse, *Vent D'Hiver*, and the lullaby she used to sing to him, a song about a river that steals the moon.

The lullaby was the key. On a hunch, Elara shifted her search from genealogical databases to ethnomusicology archives. She spent hours listening to crackling, decades-old field recordings of Métis elders, their voices thin and reedy, singing the old songs. The work was painstaking, her ear straining to catch melodies through a blizzard of static. Late on the second night, she found it. A recording made in the 1960s near St. Louis, Saskatchewan. An old woman singing a lullaby about a river and a stolen moon. In the archivist's notes, the singer was identified as Marie Dubois, and the notes mentioned that she had learned the song from her grandmother, whose brother had vanished as a young man, a trapper who was said to have “married the land.” The name, the story, the song—it all fit. It was a fragile, gossamer thread, but it was a thread she could follow.

The drive south to the Batoche region felt different from all their other journeys. This was not just a place on a map; it was a heartland, a place of immense historical weight and enduring spiritual power. The landscape was saturated with the ghosts of the 1885 Resistance, with the defiant, tragic spirit of Louis Riel, and with the resilient, unyielding memory of the Métis people. Russell felt it more acutely than ever before. The memories of Joseph rose within him, not as a haunting, but as a deep-rooted sense of belonging. He felt the supple give of a snowshoe, the heft of an axe, the particular way the willows along the South Saskatchewan River bent in the wind. He felt Joseph’s profound and easy relationship with the land, a partnership between two sovereign beings. It was a feeling entirely different from the lonely awe of the other souls, and it settled in him not as a burden, but as a quiet strength.

The address Elara had found led them to a small, modern house on the edge of the Batoche National Historic Site, overlooking the sweeping bend of the river. A woman was sitting on the front porch, weaving the vibrant, geometric patterns of a Métis sash on a small loom. She looked up as their car pulled into the gravel drive, her hands never ceasing their intricate work. She was perhaps in her late fifties, with a calm, strong face and eyes that held the same deep, knowing light as the river beside her. She watched them get out of the car, her gaze lingering on Russell with an unnerving lack of surprise. She set her loom aside as they approached. “You found us, then,” she said, her voice warm and melodic. It was not a question. “I’m Reta. Reta Dubois. My grandmother, Marie, she said someone would come one day. Someone with the rest of his song.” She looked directly at Russell, a smile of profound recognition touching her lips. “Welcome home, Grand-oncle Joseph.”Elara’s breath caught in her throat, a sharp, audible gasp in the quiet air. All the carefully prepared sentences, the gentle explanations she had rehearsed in the car, evaporated into meaningless noise. She had arrived as a historian, a bearer of a lost document, only to be met by a prophetess who had been waiting for her her entire life. Her meticulously researched, logical world collided with a reality of oral tradition and prophecy so powerful and certain that it left her feeling like an amateur, a child who had just stumbled into a conversation between adults. Beside her, Russell did not flinch. No flicker of surprise crossed his face. He simply inclined his head slightly, a gesture of quiet acknowledgement, of one sovereign power greeting another. The name Reta had called him, ‘Grand-oncle Joseph’, settled over him not like a strange new title, but like a familiar, well-worn coat he was finally being allowed to put back on.

Reta’s smile deepened, taking in Elara’s stunned silence and Russell’s profound stillness. "Don't stand out here in the wind," she said, her voice carrying the warm, practical tones of a woman used to offering hospitality. "The tea is on. Come inside." She held the screen door open, and as they stepped across the threshold, they moved from the public, contested ground of Canadian history into the private, living sanctuary of a family’s memory. The house was simple and filled with light, the air smelling of dried sweetgrass, woodsmoke, and brewing tea. Every surface held a piece of a story: a collection of smooth river stones on a windowsill, framed photographs of solemn-faced ancestors, and vibrant, intricate beadwork that seemed to pulse with a life of its own. Reta led them to a round wooden table and poured three cups of dark, fragrant tea. She did not ask for explanations. She waited with the patience of someone who knew the story was not a thing to be demanded, but a guest to be welcomed.

“My grandmother Marie spoke of you,” Reta said, her gaze moving between them. “Not you, specifically,” she clarified, nodding at Elara, “but the one who would bring the words. And she spoke of him.” Her eyes settled on Russell with a look of deep, familial affection. “She said Grand-oncle Joseph did not get lost. She said the land was lonely, and he was the only one brave enough to answer when it called. He made a trade. His life for a song, a story that would keep the connection between our people and the old ways strong. She said half the song he took with him, and half he left with her. And one day, a stranger would bring his half back, so the song could be sung whole again.” She looked at the notebook Elara had placed on the table. “You have his words. We have his reasons.”

Elara felt the foundations of her own understanding shift. The entity she had encountered in the basin, the one she had conceptualized as a lonely, consuming god, was framed here not as a taker, but as a partner in a sacred negotiation. The name 'Soul Eater' was a settler’s term, born of fear and misunderstanding. Here, in this house, that power was simply ‘the land’, a sentient relative with whom one could bargain. “We called him *l'homme qui marche avec la terre*,” Reta continued. “The man who walks with the land. He was not a ghost to us. He was an ambassador.” She picked up the sash she had been weaving, its bright colours a vibrant river in her hands. “This pattern. It’s his. My grandmother taught it to me. She said each colour tells a part of his story. The blue is the river. The green is the willow. The deep red is the heart of the land. And the single thread of white… that was the part that was missing. The part he took with him.”

The moment was too sacred for Elara to begin reading in her clinical, historian’s voice. She looked to Russell, deferring to the truth he embodied. For the first time on their journey, he initiated the telling. He reached out and lightly touched the sash in Reta’s hands. A tremor passed through him, a jolt of recognition so profound it was visible. He closed his eyes, and when he spoke, his voice was his own, yet it held the cadence and the quiet confidence of Joseph. “The wind in the winter,” he said softly. “It has a sound, out on the plains. A lonely sound. The land was afraid it was forgetting its own songs. It needed a voice to remember them.” Reta nodded, tears welling in her eyes. “And you were the only one not afraid to listen,” she whispered, completing the thought as if they were reciting a shared prayer. It was then that Elara understood her role. She was not the primary storyteller here. She was the witness, the scribe for a reunion. She opened the notebook, found the place, and her voice joined the conversation, weaving the written words into the living, breathing oral history.

The telling was a collaboration unlike any other. Elara would read a passage from the notebook, a detail of Joseph’s journey into the basin, his quiet observations of the changing landscape. Then Reta would respond, her voice rich with inherited memory, explaining the meaning of what he had seen. When Elara read of Joseph making a small offering of tobacco at a particular bend in a creek, Reta explained that this was a place known to her ancestors as a gateway, a place where the world was thin. When Elara read of the horse, *Vent D’Hiver*, turning back on its own, Reta recounted her grandmother’s story of the horse returning to the cabin alone, not panicked, but calm, as if it had simply delivered its rider to a known destination. Russell sat between them, a silent bridge connecting the two halves of the story. Occasionally, he would murmur a word in Michif, a name for a particular plant or a type of stone, a word that would make Reta gasp in recognition, a lost piece of the song returned to the melody.

As dusk settled over the valley, casting long, deep shadows, Elara read the final entry, Joseph’s last recorded thought as he stood before the altar stone: “I am ready to listen.” A profound and peaceful silence filled the small house. Reta stood up and went to a large, carved wooden chest in the corner of the room. From it, she carefully lifted a small, leather pouch, worn soft with age and decorated with a familiar, faded beadwork pattern. "My grandmother left this for you," she said, handing it to Russell. "She said you would know what to do with it." Russell took the pouch, and his fingers, which knew the secrets of engines and the heft of stones, closed around it with an innate and perfect familiarity. He opened the drawstring and tipped the contents into his palm. It was a small handful of seeds, dark and smooth and impossibly old. Sunflower seeds. The seeds of Stefan Ozeroff.

A wave of understanding, so powerful it was almost a physical blow, struck Elara. The stories were not separate. They were connected. Joseph, the ambassador, had not gone into the basin empty-handed. He had carried an offering from another lost soul, a seed of another man’s faith, planting it in the heart of the land’s memory. The connections were deeper and more intricate than she could ever have imagined. Russell looked at the seeds in his palm, and a slow, rare smile touched his lips, a smile of such pure, quiet comprehension that it transformed his face. He looked at Reta. “Thank you,” he said. And in those two simple words, he spoke for himself, for Joseph, and for Stefan. He stood, walked to the door, and stepped out into the twilight. He knelt by Reta’s garden, and with a gesture as old as agriculture itself, he pushed a single, dark seed into the rich soil of the river valley. The story was home. The offering was returned. The song was whole. He was not just returning stories; he was balancing the books of the earth, settling debts of sorrow and fulfilling promises of communion, one soul at a time.
